Continuing off of this discussion, I wanted to learn more about resolutions and hopefully eventually learn the full story that connects them with descent, local-global conditions, and potentially other concepts (such as cohomology, which also seems to be closely related to these).
To start off, my first question is about the relationship between simplicial resolutions and bar constructions/resolutions- I think I understand some of this but I just want to clarify so I'm completely clear on the connection. On nlab, they offer a way, given a comonad, to determine a simplicial resolution from it known as a comonadic resolution. Based on the article, it seems to generate something very similar to the bar construction, where the objects of the augmented simplex category are mapped to continuous applications of the monad to some object in the category the comonad is defined over. The article even also states that this comonadic resolution should be acyclic, just like we saw with bar constructions. First, is the comonadic resolution the same as the augmented simplicial object you get from the fact that Del_a^op is the walking comonoid (and so a functor will select a comonad in C's endofunctor category, which can then be followed by composition with an evaluation functor back to C), like with bar constructions? Are bar constructions a direct special case of a simplicial comonadic resolution (and if so, in what way- for instance, is it the special case when the comonoid corresponds to some monad T and the category C is EM(T))? If so, then what "nice" properties do bar constructions have that general comonadic resolutions do not, such that they "stand out" among all the comonadic resolutions?

By the way, you can link to the nLab just using square brackets, making it easier for people to look at what you're talking about. Now I'll look to see if there's an article called [[comonadic resolution]].

Okay. I don't know what a 'comonadic resolution' is, and the nLab article [[simplicial resolution]] doesn't say. So I'd be tempted to say it's just another name for the bar resolution. If anyone here knows any other 'comonadic resolutions' that aren't special cases of the bar resolution, they should say.
I would say that there's a general concept of 'simplicial resolution' that has the bar resolution as an important special case - but also has many other interesting special cases.

So, until someone tells us something interesting about 'comonadic resolutions', I recommend forgetting about comonadic resolutions and focusing on the concept of [[simplicial resolution]] and understanding 1) how the bar resolution is a special case, and 2) why the bar resolution is special.

To discuss these things cleanly, it's preferable to work with the "algebraist's simplex category", consisting of finite ordinals (including the empty ordinal) and order-preserving maps between them. I'll denote this as Δa\Delta_aΔa​. It has one more object than the topologist's Δ\DeltaΔ, which omits the empty ordinal. Under ordinal sum, Δa\Delta_aΔa​ is a strict monoidal category whose monoidal unit is the empty ordinal 0\mathbf{0}0. The terminal object 1\mathbf{1}1, the one-element ordinal, is a monoid object, as terminal objects always are. Δa\Delta_aΔa​ considered together with the monoid 1\mathbf{1}1 is sometimes called "the walking monoid": given a (strict) monoidal category M\mathbf{M}M together with a monoid object MMM, there is a unique strict monoidal functor Δa→M\Delta_a \to \mathbf{M}Δa​→M that carries the monoid structure on 1\mathbf{1}1 to the monoid structure on MMM. Similarly, Δaop\Delta_a^{op}Δaop​ is the "walking comonoid".

If A\mathbf{A}A is a category and CCC is a comonad on A\mathbf{A}A, then we may regard CCC as a comonoid object in the category of endofunctors [A,A][\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{A}][A,A], regarding the latter as a strict monoidal category under endofunctor composition. Since Δaop\Delta_a^{op}Δaop​ is the "walking comonoid", we get a unique monoidal functor

Δop→[A,A]\Delta^{op} \to [\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{A}]Δop→[A,A]

that carries the comonoid 1\mathbf{1}1 to the comonoid CCC. If, further, we have an object AAA of A\mathbf{A}A, then we have a functor evA:[A,A]→A\mathrm{ev}_A: [\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{A}] \to \mathbf{A}evA​:[A,A]→A which evaluates an endofunctor FFF at AAA, i.e., sends FFF to F(A)F(A)F(A). The evident composite

Δaop→[A,A]→evAA\Delta_a^{op} \to [\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{A}] \overset{\mathrm{ev}_A}{\to} \mathbf{A}Δaop​→[A,A]→evA​A

then defines a simplicial object in A\mathbf{A}A, and this is the basic construction we are discussing.

In simplicial language, it's actually what one calls an "augmented" simplicial object. It's augmented because we have this extra object 0\mathbf{0}0 in Δa\Delta_aΔa​, where the functor Δaop→A\Delta_a^{op} \to \mathbf{A}Δaop​→A takes 0\mathbf{0}0 to AAA, and in general takes the nnn-element ordinal n\mathbf{n}n to Cn(A)C^n(A)Cn(A). We also have this extra map 0→1\mathbf{0} \to \mathbf{1}0→1, and the functor Δaop→A\Delta_a^{op} \to \mathbf{A}Δaop​→A takes this map to an extra face map of the form C(A)→AC(A) \to AC(A)→A, and this is referred to as the augmentation. Sometimes the experts refer to the receiving object AAA of the augmentation as being in (simplicial) degree −1-1−1, so that the face maps in low degree end with the shape

…C2(A)⇉C(A)→A.\ldots C^2(A) \rightrightarrows C(A) \to A.…C2(A)⇉C(A)→A.

Now suppose we have a monad MMM on a category E\mathbf{E}E, and an MMM-algebra AAA. Let A=EM\mathbf{A} = \mathbf{E}^MA=EM be the category of MMM-algebras. There's a forgetful functor U:EM→EU: \mathbf{E}^M \to \mathbf{E}U:EM→E, with a free functor F:E→EMF: \mathbf{E} \to \mathbf{E}^MF:E→EM that is left adjoint to it. The free-forgetful adjunction induces a comonad C=FUC = FUC=FU on EM\mathbf{E}^MEM. So then we can apply the basic construction above to this situation, resulting in an augmented simplicial object

Δaop→[EM,EM]→evAEM\Delta_a^{op} \to [\mathbf{E}^M, \mathbf{E}^M] \overset{\mathrm{ev}_A}{\to} \mathbf{E}^MΔaop​→[EM,EM]→evA​EM

and this is what I (nowadays) would call the bar construction on AAA.

In my idiolect, I make a distinction between this and what I would (nowadays) call the bar resolution on AAA. The bar resolution is the augmented simplicial object in E\mathbf{E}E that we get by appending to this construction the forgetful functor UUU:

Δaop→[EM,EM]→evAEM→UE\Delta_a^{op} \to [\mathbf{E}^M, \mathbf{E}^M] \overset{\mathrm{ev}_A}{\to} \mathbf{E}^M \overset{U}{\to} \mathbf{E}Δaop​→[EM,EM]→evA​EM→UE

and this is what I would denote by B(M,M,A)B(M, M, A)B(M,M,A). The object in simplicial degree n−1n-1n−1 is UCnA=UFU…FUAU C^n A = UFU\ldots FUAUCnA=UFU…FUA, but this is the same as MnUAM^n UAMnUA.

The reason for further composing with UUU is that it allows us to pick up some extra degeneracy maps that play the role of a contracting homotopy, one that witnesses a homotopy equivalence between this augmented simplicial object, and the constant augmented simplicial object (that is constantly AAA in every simplicial degree). It's this contracting homotopy that I think of as putting the "r" in "resolution". Namely, the contracting homotopy, given by maps

B(M,M,A)n−1→B(M,M,A)n,B(M, M, A)_{n-1} \to B(M, M, A)_n,B(M,M,A)n−1​→B(M,M,A)n​,

is given by components of the unit of the monad MMM:

uMnUA:MnUA→Mn+1UA.u_{M^n UA}: M^n UA \to M^{n+1} UA.uMnUA​:MnUA→Mn+1UA.

Notice that these unit maps live in E\mathbf{E}E, not in EM\mathbf{E}^MEM (unit maps are not algebra maps!). That's why we had to map down to E\mathbf{E}E.

By the way, also notice that in this situation, the augmentation map for the MMM-algebra AAA is a coequalizer of the algebra face maps coming before it,

FUFUA⇉FUA→AFUFU A \rightrightarrows FU A \to AFUFUA⇉FUA→A

and in fact if we descend down to E\mathbf{E}E, the portion of the contracting homotopy gives a splitting of the fork

UFUFA⇉UFUA→UAUFUF A \rightrightarrows UFU A \to UAUFUFA⇉UFUA→UA

which makes this a split coequalizer, the basic sort of thing appearing in all those monadicity theorems. I thought I'd mention that, to tie this up with the nLab article on simplicial resolutions.

I wouldn't say this is "magical" and I wouldn't say it's a property of the bar construction per se. I think what it's saying is that monads describe gadgets that admit presentations in terms of generators and relations, so any algebra of a monad is, more or less by definition, obtainable from a free algebra by taking a coequalizer. This is easiest to talk about for monads on the category of sets, but the theory of monads distills that idea so it applies more generally.

For example suppose MMM is the "free group" monad on the category of sets. Then if AAA is any group, there's a free group MAMAMA with all the elements of AAA as generators, and αMA→A\alpha MA \to AαMA→A expresses AAA as a quotient of MAMAMA. Moreover it's not just that we know α\alphaα is an epimorphism with some kernel giving us the relations in our presentation. We know

MMA⇉μAMαMA→αAMMA \overset{M\alpha}{\underset{\mu A}{\rightrightarrows}} MA \overset{\alpha}{\to} AMMAμA⇉​Mα​MA→αA

is a coequalizer, and this tells us what the relations are. Elements x∈MMAx \in MMAx∈MMA are formal products of elements in our free group MAMAMA, and the relations are all the equations of the form

(Mα)(x)=(μA)(x) (M\alpha)(x) = (\mu A)(x)(Mα)(x)=(μA)(x)

This is a very "wasteful" presentation of our group AAA, since we've taken all possible group elements as generators and all possible relations between these as relations. But it's a "natural" presentation: finding it didn't require making arbitrary choices, so if we have a group homomorphism f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B we get a naturality diagram that looks like

MMA⇉μAMαMA→αAMMA \overset{M\alpha}{\underset{\mu A}{\rightrightarrows}} MA \overset{\alpha}{\to} AMMAμA⇉​Mα​MA→αA

on top and

MMB⇉μBMαMB→αBMMB \overset{M\alpha}{\underset{\mu B}{\rightrightarrows}} MB \overset{\alpha}{\to} BMMBμB⇉​Mα​MB→αB

with vertical arrows giving two naturality squares.

Well, maybe this is magical: it's great stuff. But I would say this is the magic of monads, not the bar construction - since we haven't yet invoked the simplicial object that emerges when we go further and start looking at MMMA,MMMA,MMMA, MMMMA,MMMMA, MMMMA, etc. Indeed, from this perspective it seems completely unnecessary to bring in that extra stuff. MAMAMA is describing generators, MMAMMAMMA is describing relations, but MMMAMMMAMMMA is describing relations between relations, and MMMMAMMMMAMMMMA is describing relations between relations between relations - and who gives a damn about those?

Well, it turns out they're important! Relations between relations are called "syzygies", and Hilbert's syzgy theorem showed how important these are back in 1890!

This ultimately led to a more "homological" or "homotopical" approach to monads and their algebras, in which the bar construction becomes important. First people looked at monads on abelian categories, where simplicial objects are the same as chain complexes - that's homological algebra. Historically part of what happened is that Hilbert's student Noether invented chain complexes around 1926-1928 while listening to some lectures on topology by Alexandroff and Hopf.
